elements.content: The reactions of bis(pyridylcarboxamido)propane (L 1 , 4-pyridyl and L 2 , 3-pyridyl), and bis(pyridylcarboxamido)pentane (L 3 , 4-pyridyl and L 4 , 3-pyridyl) with Cu(I/II), Co(II), and Cd(II) salts in the presence of various anions resulted in one-dimensional (1D) and two-dimensional (2D) coordination polymers containing M2L2 and M4L4 metallacycles. Reactions of L 1 and L 2 with CuI afforded the formation of two different kinds of SBUs as Cu2I2 and Cu4I4, and both complexes form 1D chains, which are assembled further by α-sheet hydrogen bonding. The reactions of M(II) salts in the absence of guest molecules lead to the formation of 1D chains containing M2L2-type metallacycles. These 1D chains are found to be of two types: in one type adjacent metallacycles are in plane with each other and in the second type they are nonparallel to each other. The reaction of Cu(II) with L 1 in the presence of guest molecules such as benzonitrile or nitrobenzene leads to the formation of corrugated 2D layers containing M4L4 metallacycles. These 2D layers exhibit 2-fold interpenetration as well as guest inclusion simultaneously and also exhibit preferential guest-exchange dynamics. The self-complementary amide groups of the ligands assembled these coordination networks into higher dimensional architectures via amide-to-amide (α-sheet), amide-to-water, amide-to-anions, and N–H···O or O–H···O hydrogen bonds. The alkyl spacers are found to exhibit various conformations depending on the coordination network geometries, anions, and guest molecules.

Reactions of L  1  and L  2  with CuI afforded the formation of two different kinds of SBUs as Cu2I2 and Cu4I4, and both complexes form 1D chains, which are assembled further by α-sheet hydrogen bonding. The reaction of Cu(II) with L  1  in the presence of guest molecules such as benzonitrile or nitrobenzene leads to the formation of corrugated 2D layers containing M4L4 metallacycles. The alkyl spacers are found to exhibit various conformations depending on the coordination network geometries, anions, and guest molecules.

elements.content: Flexible amide-based ligands, bis(pyridinecarboxamido)propanes and bis(pyridinecarboxamido)pentanes were shown to form coordination polymers with M [where M = Cu(I/II), Co(II), Cd(II)] in the presence of various anions and solvent systems. The position of the N atom in the pyridyl ring, the number of CH2 groups in the alkyl spacer, and anions and guests play an important role in the final outcome of the reactions. The network recognitions and guest and anion-exchange reactions are studied in detail.

The network recognitions and guest and anion-exchange reactions are studied in detail.

elements.content: The design and synthesis of coordination polymers (CPs) have become a subject of extensive investigation due to their intriguing architectures and functional properties. The urge to synthesize novel CP-based materials with predictable functional properties has driven the chemists to design, synthesize, and explore new ligands capable of forming extended networks upon complexation with transition metals. Notably exo-bidentate, tridentate or tetradentate ligands containing pyridyl and/or −COOH functionalities are often employed for constructing CPs. The spacers that anchor these functional groups in the ligand also play a major role in determining network geometries and properties. Aromatic spacers are often used given their rigidity and therefore unique geometry of the ligand. The use of aliphatic or aliphatic–aromatic groups as spacers introduces considerable flexibility in the molecules, which leads to the diversified network geometries depending on the reaction conditions such as metal-to-ligand ratio, counteranion, pH, temperature, solvent, or guest molecules. Recently, we and others have initiated studies on CPs based on bispyridine ligands in which the pyridyl groups are separated by three types of spacers: secondary amides and alkyl groups [−(CH2) n −] or ester and alkyl groupsor urea and alkyl groups. The spacers containing secondary amides or urea moieties were shown to provide additional support to coordination networks via hydrogen bonds. A diverse set of networks were produced just by varying the length of the alkyl chain or the position of the N-donor atom in the pyridine moiety. However, in most of such cases, the spacers considered are with an even number of −(CH2)– groups; a very limited number of studies are known with the spacers containing odd number of −(CH2)– groups. Only one complex is reported with alkanediylbis(isonicotinate) containing −(CH2)3– and Co(SCN)2. Further, the bis-pyridyl ligands containing polyethylene oxide (−CH2CH2O−) n units as spacers were also used to explore CPs. In such cases, it was shown that ligands with an odd number of −CH2CH2O– produces mostly metallacycle, while those with an even number of −CH2CH2O– produces chainlike compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and synthesis of coordination polymers (CPs) have become a subject of extensive investigation due to their intriguing architectures and functional properties. The urge to synthesize novel CP-based materials with predictable functional properties has driven the chemists to design, synthesize, and explore new ligands capable of forming extended networks upon complexation with transition metals. Notably exo-bidentate, tridentate or tetradentate ligands containing pyridyl and/or -COOH functionalities are often employed for constructing CPs. The spacers that anchor these functional groups in the ligand also play a major role in determining network geometries and properties. Aromatic spacers are often used given their rigidity and therefore unique geometry of the ligand. The use of aliphatic or aliphatic-aromatic groups as spacers introduces considerable flexibility in the molecules, which leads to the diversified network geometries depending on the reaction conditions such as metal-to-ligand ratio, counteranion, pH, temperature, solvent, or guest molecules. Recently, we and others have initiated studies on CPs based on bispyridine ligands in which the pyridyl groups are separated by three types of spacers: secondary amides and alkyl groups [-(CH2) n -] or ester and alkyl groupsor urea and alkyl groups. The spacers containing secondary amides or urea moieties were shown to provide additional support to coordination networks via hydrogen bonds. A diverse set of networks were produced just by varying the length of the alkyl chain or the position of the N-donor atom in the pyridine moiety. However, in most of such cases, the spacers considered are with an even number of -(CH2)- groups; a very limited number of studies are known with the spacers containing odd number of -(CH2)- groups. Only one complex is reported with alkanediylbis(isonicotinate) containing -(CH2)3- and Co(SCN)2. Further, the bis-pyridyl ligands containing polyethylene oxide (-CH2CH2O-) n  units as spacers were also used to explore CPs. In such cases, it was shown that ligands with an odd number of -CH2CH2O- produces mostly metallacycle, while those with an even number of -CH2CH2O- produces chainlike compounds.

elements.content: Recently, we have analyzed the crystal structures of the homologous series of bis(pyridylcarboxamido)alkane, I, and bis(pyridyl)alkanediamides derivatives, II (Scheme ). In the case of II, the derivatives containing an odd number of −(CH2)– groups in the alkyl spacer were found to exhibit interesting structural and physical properties, which differ significantly from those of their even analogues. Further, we have also explored the CPs of I and II, in which the spacers contain an even number of −(CH2)– groups, in the presence of various anions and solvent systems and studied their guest and anion exchange properties. These studies revealed that CPs containing ligands with shorter spacers such as −(CH2)2– or −(CH2)4– exhibit versatility in producing one-dimensional (1D) chains containing cavities, open two-dimensional (2D) networks, chiral 2D networks, interpenetrated 2D networks (both parallel and perpendicular modes), and three-dimensional (3D) pseudodiamondoid. On the other hand, the ligands with phenyl, hexyl, or octyl spacers have consistently formed 2D-networks, which are further linked by amide-to-amide hydrogen bonds. The isostructurality between CPs of I and II were also observed with the ligands containing longer spacers.

These studies revealed that CPs containing ligands with shorter spacers such as -(CH2)2- or -(CH2)4- exhibit versatility in producing one-dimensional (1D) chains containing cavities, open two-dimensional (2D) networks, chiral 2D networks, interpenetrated 2D networks (both parallel and perpendicular modes), and three-dimensional (3D) pseudodiamondoid. On the other hand, the ligands with phenyl, hexyl, or octyl spacers have consistently formed 2D-networks, which are further linked by amide-to-amide hydrogen bonds. The isostructurality between CPs of I and II were also observed with the ligands containing longer spacers.

In this contribution, the influence of the presence of an odd number of −(CH2)– groups in the alkyl spacer of I on the formation of CPs and geometries of CPs will be explored by considering the ligands L 1 –L 4 (Scheme ). A total of 10 crystalline complexes have been synthesized and analyzed in terms of various factors such as counteranions, guest molecules, and position of the N atom in pyridyl rings on the occurrence of amide-to-amide hydrogen bonds. Our study suggested that predictability of network is more in the case of the odd ones. In the absence of guests, the odd ligands (L 1 –L 4 ) consistently form 1D chains containing metallacylces of the M2L2 type, and in the presence of a guest, a novel 2D interpenetrated network with inclusion of guest-containing metallacylces of the M4L4 type has been produced.
elements.clean_text: In this contribution, the influence of the presence of an odd number of -(CH2)- groups in the alkyl spacer of I on the formation of CPs and geometries of CPs will be explored by considering the ligands L  1 -L  4  (Scheme ). A total of 10 crystalline complexes have been synthesized and analyzed in terms of various factors such as counteranions, guest molecules, and position of the N atom in pyridyl rings on the occurrence of amide-to-amide hydrogen bonds. Our study suggested that predictability of network is more in the case of the odd ones. In the absence of guests, the odd ligands (L  1 -L  4 ) consistently form 1D chains containing metallacylces of the M2L2 type, and in the presence of a guest, a novel 2D interpenetrated network with inclusion of guest-containing metallacylces of the M4L4 type has been produced.

elements.content: The ligands L 1 –L 4 were synthesized by previously reported procedures. The complexation reactions were carried out either by direct mixing of the ligands with the transition metal salts in MeOH or by the layering procedures. The single crystals of complexes 1 and 2 were obtained by layering the acetonitrile solution of CuI over the dichloromethane solution of corresponding ligands, whereas direct mixing of the methanolic solutions of the ligand and Cu(II)/Co(II)/Cd(II) salts of ClO4 and PF6 in a 2:1 molar ratio yielded complexes 3–8. Complexes 9 and 10 were also produced by direct mixing in the presence of aromatic guests. The reaction of L 1 with Cu(ClO4)2 in the presence of benzonitrile and nitrobenzene afforded complexes 9 and 10, respectively: [(Cu2I2)(L 1 )2] n , 1, [(Cu4I4)(L 2 )2] n , 2, {[Cu2(L 1 )4(H2O)4)(PF6)4]·5(H2O)} n , 3, {[Cu(L 1 )2(H2O)2)(ClO4)2]·2(H2O)} n , 4, {[Cu(L 3 )2(H2O)2)(ClO4)2]·2(H2O)·4(CH3OH)} n , 5, {[Co(L 2 )2(H2O)2](ClO4)2} n , 6, {[Cd(L 2 )2(H2O)2](ClO4)2} n , 7, {[Cu(L 4 )2(H2O)2)(PF6)2]·2(H2O)} n , 8, {[Cu(L 1 )2(H2O)2)(ClO4)2]·2(H2O)·(benzonitrile)} n , 9, {[Cu(L 1 )2(H2O)2(ClO4)2]·2(H2O)·(nitrobenzene)} n , 10.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The ligands L  1 -L  4  were synthesized by previously reported procedures. The complexation reactions were carried out either by direct mixing of the ligands with the transition metal salts in MeOH or by the layering procedures. The single crystals of complexes 1 and 2 were obtained by layering the acetonitrile solution of CuI over the dichloromethane solution of corresponding ligands, whereas direct mixing of the methanolic solutions of the ligand and Cu(II)/Co(II)/Cd(II) salts of ClO4 and PF6 in a 2:1 molar ratio yielded complexes 3-8. Complexes 9 and 10 were also produced by direct mixing in the presence of aromatic guests. The reaction of L  1  with Cu(ClO4)2 in the presence of benzonitrile and nitrobenzene afforded complexes 9 and 10, respectively: [(Cu2I2)(L  1 )2] n , 1, [(Cu4I4)(L  2 )2] n , 2, {[Cu2(L  1 )4(H2O)4)(PF6)4]⋅5(H2O)} n , 3, {[Cu(L  1 )2(H2O)2)(ClO4)2]⋅2(H2O)} n , 4, {[Cu(L  3 )2(H2O)2)(ClO4)2]⋅2(H2O)⋅4(CH3OH)} n , 5, {[Co(L  2 )2(H2O)2](ClO4)2} n , 6, {[Cd(L  2 )2(H2O)2](ClO4)2} n , 7, {[Cu(L  4 )2(H2O)2)(PF6)2]⋅2(H2O)} n , 8, {[Cu(L  1 )2(H2O)2)(ClO4)2]⋅2(H2O)⋅(benzonitrile)} n , 9, {[Cu(L  1 )2(H2O)2(ClO4)2]⋅2(H2O)⋅(nitrobenzene)} n , 10.

elements.content: The crystal structures of complexes 1–10 were determined and analyzed in terms of ligand geometries, coordination network geometries, recognition of networks through amide-to-amide hydrogen bonds, and the effect of anions and guest molecules. The pertinent crystallographic details, bond lengths around metal center and geometrical parameters of N–H···O and C–H···O hydrogen bonds involving amides, are given in Tables –, respectively.

The diffusion of a CH3CN solution of CuI into a CH2Cl2–MeOH solution of ligands L 1 and L 2 resulted in bright-orange-colored crystals of 1 and light yellow crystals of’ 2, respectively. Although both form 1D networks containing cavities, they differ significantly. The asymmetric unit of 1 is constituted by one unit each of Cu(I), I– and L 1 , while that of 2 is constituted by two units each of Cu(I) and I– and one unit of L 2 . The Cu(I) and I– form Cu2I2 and Cu4I4 secondary building units (SBU) in 1 and 2, respectively (Figures and ). Both are four-connected SBUs; the Cu2I2 acts as a square planar node, while Cu4I4 acts as a tetrahedral node. It is interesting to note here that bis(3-pyridylcarboxamido)ethane with CuI was shown to form open and doubly interpenetrated [4,4]-networks (parallel mode) via Cu2I2 and Cu4I4 SBUs, respectively. In both those cases, the [4,4] networks are joined via β-sheet hydrogen bonds. However, in the present case, the ligands exhibit curvature; as a result, both form 1D chains containing cavities. The ligand L 1 in 1 is twisted; the N–CH2–CH2–CH2–N moiety exhibits syn–syn geometry, such that there exists an intramolecular N–H···O hydrogen bond which is not observed for L 2 in 2 (Figures b and d). The ligand L 2 adopts convergent geometry as the amide and 3-pyridyl moieties are syn to each other with N–CH2–CH2–CH2–N exhibiting syn–anti geometry. As the node Cu2I2 in 1 exhibits square planar geometry, the adjacent loops are parallel to each other, while they are perpendicular in 2 due to the tetrahedral nature of the Cu4I4 unit. In 1, the 1D networks interact with each other through amide-to-amide hydrogen bonding and form a 2D hydrogen-bonded layer (Figure c). In 2, the α-sheet hydrogen bonding between the ligands (along the b axis) leads to the formation of a 3D network (Figure , panels c and d). It is noteworthy here that just a change in 4-pyridyl to 3-pyridyl results in several differences in terms of building blocks, network geometries, and their assembly via hydrogen bonds.

4-Connected 1D-Networks via SBUs and Contain Amide-to-Amide Recognition

The diffusion of a CH3CN solution of CuI into a CH2Cl2-MeOH solution of ligands L  1  and L  2  resulted in bright-orange-colored crystals of 1 and light yellow crystals of' 2, respectively. Although both form 1D networks containing cavities, they differ significantly. The asymmetric unit of 1 is constituted by one unit each of Cu(I), I- and L  1 , while that of 2 is constituted by two units each of Cu(I) and I- and one unit of L  2 . The Cu(I) and I- form Cu2I2 and Cu4I4 secondary building units (SBU) in 1 and 2, respectively (Figures  and ). Both are four-connected SBUs; the Cu2I2 acts as a square planar node, while Cu4I4 acts as a tetrahedral node. It is interesting to note here that bis(3-pyridylcarboxamido)ethane with CuI was shown to form open and doubly interpenetrated [4,4]-networks (parallel mode) via Cu2I2 and Cu4I4 SBUs, respectively. In both those cases, the [4,4] networks are joined via β-sheet hydrogen bonds. However, in the present case, the ligands exhibit curvature; as a result, both form 1D chains containing cavities. The ligand L  1  in 1 is twisted; the N-CH2-CH2-CH2-N moiety exhibits syn-syn geometry, such that there exists an intramolecular N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bond which is not observed for L  2  in 2 (Figures b and d). The ligand L  2  adopts convergent geometry as the amide and 3-pyridyl moieties are syn to each other with N-CH2-CH2-CH2-N exhibiting syn-anti geometry. As the node Cu2I2 in 1 exhibits square planar geometry, the adjacent loops are parallel to each other, while they are perpendicular in 2 due to the tetrahedral nature of the Cu4I4 unit. In 1, the 1D networks interact with each other through amide-to-amide hydrogen bonding and form a 2D hydrogen-bonded layer (Figure c). In 2, the α-sheet hydrogen bonding between the ligands (along the b axis) leads to the formation of a 3D network (Figure , panels c and d). elements.clean_text:
4-Connected 1D Networks with Adjacent Metallacycles Parallel to Each Other

Unlike the above-described complexes of halide salts of Cu(I), the PF6 and ClO4 salts of Cu(II) do not form SBUs, and the single metal ion acts as a node and propagates the networks in a similar fashion.

elements.content: The reactions of L 1 with Cu(PF6)2 and Cu(ClO4)2 in the water–MeOH solvent system afforded complexes 3 and 4, respectively. Crystal structures of these complexes reveal that both form a similar type of 1D chains. The complex 3 crystallizes in the P21 /c space group, and the asymmetric unit is composed of four crystallographically independent L 1 units, two Cu(II) ions, four PF6 ions, and nine H2O molecules. While the complex 4 crystallizes in the P212121 chiral space group and asymmetric unit is constituted by one Cu(II), two L 1 units, two ClO4 – ions, and four water molecules. In both cases, the Cu(II) ion adopts a distorted octahedral geometry, as four units of L 1 occupy the equatorial positions and two H2O molecules occupy the axial positions (Figures and ). The geometry of the ligands in both cases are found to be convergent in terms of placement of the N atoms of the pyridine groups, leading to the formation of 4-connected 1D chains containing cavities. The cavities are occupied by anions and free water molecules, which interact with the coordinated water molecules and amide O, respectively.

elements.content: In complex 3, only two of the four amide groups are engaged in amide-to-amide hydrogen bonds. The N–H groups of the remaining two amides form hydrogen bonds with the H2O molecules. The packing of the 1D chains (3 and 4) is somewhat complicated in the sense that it has two types of association with adjacent chains. On one side of the chain, the association (type-1) takes place such that the metal ions of the adjacent chains are in line along the c axis. On the other side, the association (type 2) takes place such that the metal ions of the adjacent chains are arranged in an offset fashion (along the c axis). In type-1 packing, the association of the chains take place via hydrogen bonds between the ligand, H2O, and the anions (Figure , panels c and d). In other words, in 3, this packing is governed by the α-sheet hydrogen bonding, albeit with the insertion of H2O molecules between alternate dimers. In the type-2 packing, the coordinated water molecules hydrogen bond with two carbonyl groups of the same ligand of the next neighboring chain (Figure e).

elements.content:
In the case of 4, the type-1 was not constituted by the α sheet, as only one amide links the chains through water molecules (Figure c). But the type-2 packing is similar to that of 3 (Figure d).

The longer ligand L 3 was found to form suitable single crystals (5), only with Cu(ClO4)2 but not with Cu(PF6)2. The complex 5 crystallizes in the P4̅ space group, and the asymmetric unit is constituted by a half unit of Cu(II), two 1/4 units of ClO4 ions, one unit of L 3 , and solvent molecules, which could not be located (30% of the crystal volume). The Cu(II) adopts an octahedral environment where the four ligands occupy equatorial sites, and the axial position is occupied by water molecules (Figure ). The ligand L 3 exhibits convergent geometry similar to L 1 but contains twisted geometry, that is the two amido-pyridine units make an interplanar angle of 77.34°, while the same in 4 is 88.71° and 84.13°. The 1D chains contain nearly planar geometry similar to the ones observed in 3 and 4; however, their packing differs significantly. The 1D chains interact with adjacent chains in a perpendicular fashion via hydrogen bonds between the amide groups and water molecules to form a tubular structure containing continuous channels, along the c axis, which are occupied by ClO4 – ions and solvent molecules.

elements.content: It is interesting to note here that complex 3 shows the ability to exchange anions when immersed in a methanolic solution of NaClO4. The quality of crystals deteriorates and diffracted too weakly to give structural information. However, complete exchange of PF6 – by ClO4 – was confirmed by elemental analysis and IR spectra (see the ). The PXRD pattern of the sample prepared by exchange matches with that of the as-synthesized one, which rules out any structural change during the exchange process (Figure S2 of the ).
elements.clean_text:
Anion Exchange Reactions in Complexes 3 and 4 

It is interesting to note here that complex 3 shows the ability to exchange anions when immersed in a methanolic solution of NaClO4. The quality of crystals deteriorates and diffracted too weakly to give structural information. However, complete exchange of PF6 - by ClO4 - was confirmed by elemental analysis and IR spectra (see the ). The PXRD pattern of the sample prepared by exchange matches with that of the as-synthesized one, which rules out any structural change during the exchange process (Figure S2 of the ).

elements.content: To investigate the exchange of the ClO4 ion in 4 by the PF6 ion, the crystals of complex 4 were dipped into a methanolic solution of NH4PF6 in a similar way. Similar to 3, the crystals lost crystallinity, but the complete exchange of ClO4 by the PF6 ion was confirmed by elemental analysis and IR spectra (see the ). The PXRD pattern of the exchanged sample matches with that of the as-synthesized one, suggesting the conservation of the network (Figure S2 of the ).

The PXRD pattern of the exchanged sample matches with that of the as-synthesized one, suggesting the conservation of the network (Figure S2 of the ).

elements.content: The complexation reactions of L 2 with ClO4 or PF6 salts of Cu(II) were not successful in affording single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction. However, the reactions of L 2 with perchlorate salts of Co(II) and Cd(II) afforded suitable single crystals of two iso-structural complexes 6 and 7, respectively. These complexes crystallize in the C2/c space group, and the asymmetric unit contains M(II) with 0.5 occupancy and one unit each of ligand L 2 , the perchlorate ion, and the water molecule. The central metal ions adopt an octahedral environment, but unlike other complexes syn coordination of the ligand is observed as three of the four ligands that occupy equatorial sites, and the fourth one coordinates to an axial position (Figure ). Due to the syn coordinaton of the ligands, the 1D chain exhibits nonplanar geometry and the planes (passing through two metal ions and the central C atom) of two adjacent loops makes an angle of ∼60°. The 1D chains stack on each other along the b axis with metal-to-metal separation of 7.2 Å, such that there are continuous channels along the cavities of the 1D chains. These channels are occupied by ClO4 anions, which are hydrogen bonded to amide N–H groups (Figure , panels d and f). Consequently, no amide-to-amide recognition was observed in complexes 6 and 7. Stacking of the chains was governed by the weak C–H···π interactions in the ac plane.
elements.clean_text:
4-Connected 1D Networks with Adjacent Metallacycles Having Twisted Orientations

The complexation reactions of L  2  with ClO4 or PF6 salts of Cu(II) were not successful in affording single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction. However, the reactions of L  2  with perchlorate salts of Co(II) and Cd(II) afforded suitable single crystals of two iso-structural complexes 6 and 7, respectively. These complexes crystallize in the C2/c space group, and the asymmetric unit contains M(II) with 0.5 occupancy and one unit each of ligand L  2 , the perchlorate ion, and the water molecule. The central metal ions adopt an octahedral environment, but unlike other complexes syn coordination of the ligand is observed as three of the four ligands that occupy equatorial sites, and the fourth one coordinates to an axial position (Figure ). Due to the syn coordinaton of the ligands, the 1D chain exhibits nonplanar geometry and the planes (passing through two metal ions and the central C atom) of two adjacent loops makes an angle of ~60°. The 1D chains stack on each other along the b axis with metal-to-metal separation of 7.2 Å, such that there are continuous channels along the cavities of the 1D chains. These channels are occupied by ClO4 anions, which are hydrogen bonded to amide N-H groups (Figure , panels d and f). Consequently, no amide-to-amide recognition was observed in complexes 6 and 7. Stacking of the chains was governed by the weak C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions in the ac plane.

elements.content: The bigger analogue L 4 was found to form single crystals, complex 8, with only Cu(PF6)2 but not with Cu(ClO4)2 or Cd(II) or Co(II) salts. The complex 8 crystallizes in the C2/c space group, and the asymmetric unit is constituted by Cu(II) with 0.5 occupancy, one unit each of L 4 and PF6 ion, and two molecules of water. The Cu(II) ion adopts an octahedral environment. Unlike complexes 6 and 7, here four ligands occupy equatorial sites, and the axial position is occupied by water molecules (Figure ), and, however, forms nonplanar 1D chains similar to 6 and 7. The nonplanarity of the 1D chain can be attributed to the coordination mode of the 3-pyridyl moiety of L 4 as well as the gauche–anti-gauche conformation adopted by the pentyl spacer of L 4 . The planes (passing through two metal ions and the central C atom) of two adjacent loops of the 1D-chain makes an angle of ∼40°. The packing of the chains takes place similar to the complexes of 6 and 7.

elements.content: It was described above that the reaction of L 1 with Cu(ClO4)2 produced the crystals of complex 3. Interestingly, a repeat of the reaction in the presence of benzonitrile or nitrobenzene afforded single crystals of complexes 9 and 10, respectively. We note here that the repeat of other reactions reported here in a similar manner did not produce any more new crystals.
elements.clean_text:
2D-Networks with (4,4)-geometry, Parallel Interpenetration, and Guest Inclusion

It was described above that the reaction of L  1  with Cu(ClO4)2 produced the crystals of complex 3. Interestingly, a repeat of the reaction in the presence of benzonitrile or nitrobenzene afforded single crystals of complexes 9 and 10, respectively. We note here that the repeat of other reactions reported here in a similar manner did not produce any more new crystals.

elements.content: The complexes 9 and 10 crystallize in Pccn and P21 /c space groups, respectively. The asymmetric unit of 9 is constituted by Cu(II) with 0.5 occupancy, one unit each of L 1 and perchlorate, two water molecules, and a half unit of a benzonitrile guest. The asymmetric unit of 10 contains double the contents of that of 9. In both cases, the N–C–C–C–N spacer of L 1 exhibits all gauche conformation with torsion angles of 67.12°, 67.82° and 67.12°, 64.67° for 9 and 10, respectively, and divergent geometry (Figure ). Accordingly, both complexes 9 and 10 form a similar (4,4)-network containing wavy geometry and cavities (24.2 × 17.1 Å2 and 23.7 × 17.0 Å2 for 9 and 10, respectively). Due to the waviness of the layers, two of such networks interpenetrate such that there exist continuous channels between the interpenetrated layers (Figure , panels c and d). In the channels, the guest molecules form 1D polar columns via C–H···N and C–H···O interactions in 9 and 10, respectively. In these polar columns, the planes of benzonitrile molecules are nearly perpendicular to each other (Figure e), while those of nitrobenzene molecules make an interplanar angle of 57° (Figure f). The guest occupied volume accounts for 16% of the crystal volume. The interpenetrated layers pack in 3D via hydrogen bonds between amides, H2O molecules, and perchlorate ions; no amide-to-amide hydrogen bonds are observed in these structures.
elements.clean_text: The complexes 9 and 10 crystallize in Pccn and P21 /c space groups, respectively. The asymmetric unit of 9 is constituted by Cu(II) with 0.5 occupancy, one unit each of L  1  and perchlorate, two water molecules, and a half unit of a benzonitrile guest. The asymmetric unit of 10 contains double the contents of that of 9. In both cases, the N-C-C-C-N spacer of L  1  exhibits all gauche conformation with torsion angles of 67.12°, 67.82° and 67.12°, 64.67° for 9 and 10, respectively, and divergent geometry (Figure ). Accordingly, both complexes 9 and 10 form a similar (4,4)-network containing wavy geometry and cavities (24.2 × 17.1 Å2 and 23.7 × 17.0 Å2 for 9 and 10, respectively). Due to the waviness of the layers, two of such networks interpenetrate such that there exist continuous channels between the interpenetrated layers (Figure , panels c and d). In the channels, the guest molecules form 1D polar columns via C-H⋅⋅⋅N and C-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions in 9 and 10, respectively. In these polar columns, the planes of benzonitrile molecules are nearly perpendicular to each other (Figure e), while those of nitrobenzene molecules make an interplanar angle of 57° (Figure f). The guest occupied volume accounts for 16% of the crystal volume. The interpenetrated layers pack in 3D via hydrogen bonds between amides, H2O molecules, and perchlorate ions; no amide-to-amide hydrogen bonds are observed in these structures.

elements.content: We note that the interpenetrated 2D networks observed here are different from those observed with Cu(II) and similar ligands with spacers containing even numbers of −(CH2)– groups in our previous works. In those networks, the 2-fold interpenetration happens in the perpendicular mode, and the channels/cavities are just enough to accommodate anions. Further, the repetition of the reactions by using other aromatic guests such as halobenzene, benzyl alcohol, p-xylene, and toluene in place of benzonitrile resulted in the crystals of complex 3.

elements.content: Further, the crystals of 9 have shown ability to convert into those of 10 when immersed in nitrobenzene. However, it was found that the exchange process deteriorated the quality of crystals, making it difficult to prove it by single crystal X-ray. Nonetheless, the exchange was confirmed by elemental analysis, IR, PXRD, and TGA. The absence of the CN characteristic band of benzonitrile at 2229 cm–1 and the appearance of the N–O stretching bands (1346 and 1527 cm–1) in the IR spectra of guest-exchanged materials with nitrobenzene confirms the complete exchange of benzonitrile guests. The PXRD pattern of the exchanged sample matches with that of the as-synthesized, one suggesting that the network remains intact upon guest exchange (Figure S2 of the ). However, the reverse exchange of nitrobenzene by benzonitrile was found to be unsuccessful.
elements.clean_text:
Conversion of 9 to 10 by Guest Exchange

Further, the crystals of 9 have shown ability to convert into those of 10 when immersed in nitrobenzene. However, it was found that the exchange process deteriorated the quality of crystals, making it difficult to prove it by single crystal X-ray. Nonetheless, the exchange was confirmed by elemental analysis, IR, PXRD, and TGA. The absence of the CN characteristic band of benzonitrile at 2229 cm-1 and the appearance of the N-O stretching bands (1346 and 1527 cm-1) in the IR spectra of guest-exchanged materials with nitrobenzene confirms the complete exchange of benzonitrile guests. The PXRD pattern of the exchanged sample matches with that of the as-synthesized, one suggesting that the network remains intact upon guest exchange (Figure S2 of the ). However, the reverse exchange of nitrobenzene by benzonitrile was found to be unsuccessful.

elements.content: The optical properties of complexes 1 and 2 were measured with solid-state UV and luminescence spectra at room temperature (Figure ). Two bands appear at around 500 and 400 nm for complexes 1 and 2, respectively, in solid-state diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS). Luminescence measurements, at an excitation wavelength of 325 nm, display λmax em at around 604 nm (highly intense) and 577 nm for complexes 1 and 2, respectively. Complex 1 exhibits a Cu2I2 cluster and Cu–Cu distances of 2.625(2) and 2.635(2) Å, while complex 2 exhibits a Cu4I4 cluster and Cu–Cu distances vary from 2.584(2)–3.042(2) Å, with a mean distance of 2.723 Å. In both the complexes, the Cu–Cu distances are shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii (2.8 Å), suggesting strong interactions among the Cu(I) centers, which are responsible for the luminescence behavior of the complexes. The observed values as well as the colors of the crystals for Cu4I4 (light yellow or colorless) and Cu2I2 (deep orange) complexes are in close agreement with the literature reports.

elements.content: Similar to the ligands containing an even number of −(CH2)– groups, the ligands L 1 –L 4 have shown the better tendency to form crystalline complexes with Cu(II) salts than other M(II) [Cd(II), Co(II), Ni(II), and Mn(II)] salts. For example, out of the 10 complexes obtained here, 8 are with Cu(I/II) salts. Further, the ligands with propyl spacers (L 1 and L 2 ) have shown the better tendency for yielding the crystalline CPs (8 out of 10 complexes) than those with pentyl spacers. A similar tendency was also noted in the complexation reactions of even analogues. The gradual increase in the aliphatic nature of the ligand decreases the complexation ability of the ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Similar to the ligands containing an even number of -(CH2)- groups, the ligands L  1 -L  4  have shown the better tendency to form crystalline complexes with Cu(II) salts than other M(II) [Cd(II), Co(II), Ni(II), and Mn(II)] salts. For example, out of the 10 complexes obtained here, 8 are with Cu(I/II) salts. Further, the ligands with propyl spacers (L  1  and L  2 ) have shown the better tendency for yielding the crystalline CPs (8 out of 10 complexes) than those with pentyl spacers. A similar tendency was also noted in the complexation reactions of even analogues. The gradual increase in the aliphatic nature of the ligand decreases the complexation ability of the ligand.

elements.content: We note here that out of 10 complexes reported, six of the complexes (3–5, 8–10) contain octahedral Cu(II) metal centers, in which the equatorial sites are occupied by N atoms of the ligand, while the axial positions are occupied by O atoms of water molecules. In these complexes, the d M–N and d M–O vary from 2.002(9)–2.044(6) Å and 2.328(8)–2.641(9) Å, respectively, suggesting a distortion of the octahedral environment resulting in the elongation of the axial bond distances (Table ) due to the Jahn–Teller effect.

In these complexes, the d M-N and d M-O vary from 2.002(9)-2.044(6) Å and 2.328(8)-2.641(9) Å, respectively, suggesting a distortion of the octahedral environment resulting in the elongation of the axial bond distances (Table ) due to the Jahn-Teller effect.

elements.content: In the complexes of ligands with even number of −(CH2)– groups, the chains/layers were assembled via β-sheet hydrogen bonds; the amide groups exhibited amide-to-amide (β-sheet) as well as amide-to-solvents/anions hydrogen bonds. But in the complexes of an odd-spacer [(CH2)3/5] ligand, the amide groups are mostly hydrogen bonded to anions/solvents. Here, out of 10 complexes, amide-to-amide recognition is observed in only 5 complexes (1, 2, 3, 5, and 8). Among these five complexes, only complex 2 exhibits a rarely observed continuous α-sheet network, and complex 5 possesses an unprecedented helical hydrogen=bonding pattern in these series of complexes. Complex 1 has both inter- and intramolecular amide-to-amide recognition, while complexes 3 and 8 exhibit discrete β-sheet- and α-sheet-type hydrogen bonding. It is noteworthy that, in the case of an even analogue, β-sheet structure was observed, even in the presence of an interfering anion like ClO4, but in the present case, such a hydrogen-bonding network (α-sheet) is formed only in the presence of non-interfering anion iodide.

elements.content: The complexes with the ligand containing (CH2)2/4 as spacers exhibited versatility to accommodate a wide range of aromatic guest molecules, but those of ligands containing (CH2)3/5 as the spacer did not show a tendency to include guest molecules. The only exceptions are the complexes 9 and 10 which accommodate guests owing to the parallel interpenetration of wavy 2D layers. These studies demonstrate the importance of alkyl spacer, anions, and the presence of guest molecules in the modulation of network geometries.

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data were recorded under an N2 atmosphere at a heating rate of 5 °C min–1 with a Perkin-Elmer instrument, Pyris Diamond TG/DTA. elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General

Fourier transform-IR (FT-IR) spectra were recorded with a Perkin-Elmer Instrument Spectrum Rx Serial No. 73713. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data were recorded under an N2 atmosphere at a heating rate of 5 °C min-1 with a Perkin-Elmer instrument, Pyris Diamond TG/DTA. Elemental analysis has been carried out by Perkin-Elmer Series II 2400, and the powder XRD patterns were recorded with a Bruker APEX-2 diffractometer.

elements.content: The single crystal data were collected on a Bruker APEX-2 CCD X-ray diffractometer that uses graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) by a hemisphere method. The structures are solved by direct methods and refined by least-squares methods on F 2, using SHELX-97. Nonhydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were fixed at calculated positions and refined using a riding model. PLATON was used for the calculation of guest available volumes and squeeze option was used for disordered and unlocated anions and guest molecules. In the case of 4, one of the ClO4 ions was disordered and refined using the SQUEEZE option in the final refinement. In 5, the solvent molecules (30% of unit cell volume) and perchlorate ions (18% of the unit cell volume) could not be located; therefore, the squeeze option was used in the final refinement. Similarly in 8, both PF6 ions could not be located; therefore, the PLATON SQUEEZE option was used in the final refinement.

Syntheses of Complexes 1-2 by Layering

1.0 mL of acetonitrile was layered on to an MeOH(0.2 mL)/CH2Cl2(5.0 mL) solution (5.2 mL) of L  1  (0.015 g, 0.053 mmol). Yield: 65%. Elemental anal. Calcd for C30H32Cu2I2N8O4 (%): C, 37.95; H, 3.40; N, 11.80. Obsd (%): C, 37.90; H, 3.49; N, 11.87.

Complex <bold>2</bold>

Yield: 70%. Elemental anal. Calcd for C31H38Cl6Cu4I4N8O4 (%): C, 23.85; H, 2.45; N, 7.18. Obsd (%): C, 23.79; H, 2.57; N, 7.25.

Complex Preparations without GuestComplex <bold>3</bold>

Prepared by dissolving L 1 (0.015 g, 0.053 mmol) in 2.0 mL of MeOH. To the above solution, addition of a methanolic solution (2.0 mL) of Cu(PF6)2·(0.024 mmol) [prepared by taking nitrate salts of Cu(II) and NH4PF6 in a 1:2 ratio] resulted in the formation of a blue precipitate. After 5–10 min of stirring, 2 mL of water was added to the solution. The blue precipitate became soluble, and a clear solution was obtained. This solution was filtered and kept for slow evaporation. Blue crystals were formed after 8–10 days. A similar procedure was adopted for the synthesis of complexes 4–8.

Complex 1 exhibits a Cu2I2 cluster and Cu-Cu distances of 2.625(2) and 2.635(2) Å, while complex 2 exhibits a Cu4I4 cluster and Cu-Cu distances vary from 2.584(2)-3.042(2) Å, with a mean distance of 2.723 Å. In both the complexes, the Cu-Cu distances are shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii (2.8 Å), suggesting strong interactions among the Cu(I) centers, which are responsible for the luminescence behavior of the complexes. The observed values as well as the colors of the crystals for Cu4I4 (light yellow or colorless) and Cu2I2 (deep orange) complexes are in close agreement with the literature reports.

cln_elements.content: Illustrations for the crystal structure 2: (a) 1D chain with rectangular cavities, (b) Cu4I4 SBU, (c) packing of the 1D chains, and (d) amide-to-amide hydrogen bonding between the chains and α-sheet network.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Illustrations for the crystal structure 2: (a) 1D chain with rectangular cavities, (b) Cu4I4 SBU, (c) packing of the 1D chains, and (d) amide-to-amide hydrogen bonding between the chains and α-sheet network.

cln_elements.content: Illustrations for the crystal structure 3: (a) 1D chains with rectangular cavities occupied by PF6 ions. (b) Packing of chains, via water molecules (α-sheet, type-1 packing); the parts enclosed in the rectangle and oval are shown in panels (c) and (e), respectively. (c) Top view and (d) side view of the α-sheet. (e) Hydrogen bonding between the coordinated water molecules and the carbonyl group (type-2 packing) and (f) 3D packing of the chains.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Illustrations for the crystal structure 3: (a) 1D chains with rectangular cavities occupied by PF6 ions. (b) Packing of chains, via water molecules (α-sheet, type-1 packing); the parts enclosed in the rectangle and oval are shown in panels (c) and (e), respectively. (c) Top view and (d) side view of the α-sheet. (e) Hydrogen bonding between the coordinated water molecules and the carbonyl group (type-2 packing) and (f) 3D packing of the chains.

cln_elements.content: Illustrations for the crystal structure of 4: (a) 1D chains with rectangular cavities, and the (b) packing of chains, where the parts enclosed in the oval and rectangle are shown in panels (c) and (d), respectively. (c) Type-1 packing is not observed. (d) Interaction between the coordinated water molecules, the carbonyl group (type-2 packing), and (e) the 3D packing of chains.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  Illustrations for the crystal structure of 4: (a) 1D chains with rectangular cavities, and the (b) packing of chains, where the parts enclosed in the oval and rectangle are shown in panels (c) and (d), respectively. (c) Type-1 packing is not observed. (d) Interaction between the coordinated water molecules, the carbonyl group (type-2 packing), and (e) the 3D packing of chains.

cln_elements.content: Illustrations for the crystal structure of 5: (a) 1D chain containing rectangular cavities and (b) the coordination mode of L 3 with Cu(II); packing of 1D chains in the (c) top view and (d) side view, notice in the amide-to-amide hydrogen bonding and (e) 3D packing via amide-to-amide hydrogen bond, the channels are occupied by solvent molecules.
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  Illustrations for the crystal structure of 5: (a) 1D chain containing rectangular cavities and (b) the coordination mode of L  3  with Cu(II); packing of 1D chains in the (c) top view and (d) side view, notice in the amide-to-amide hydrogen bonding and (e) 3D packing via amide-to-amide hydrogen bond, the channels are occupied by solvent molecules.

cln_elements.content: Illustrations for the crystal structures of 6 and 7: 1D chain containing twisted metallacylces. The amide N–H groups hydrogen bond with the ClO4 ion (a) 6 and (b) 7. (c) Syn coordination of L 2 . (d) Side and (e) top views of the 1D network. The channels formed by the packing of the chains are occupied by the ClO4 ion. (f) 3D Packing of the chains via the O–H···O interaction.
cln_elements.clean_text: 6  Illustrations for the crystal structures of 6 and 7: 1D chain containing twisted metallacylces. The amide N-H groups hydrogen bond with the ClO4 ion (a) 6 and (b) 7. (c) Syn coordination of L  2 . (d) Side and (e) top views of the 1D network. The channels formed by the packing of the chains are occupied by the ClO4 ion. (f) 3D Packing of the chains via the O-H⋅⋅⋅O interaction.

cln_elements.content: Illustrations for the crystal structure of 8: (a) 1D chain containing rectangular cavities which are occupied by water and PF6 ions (b) coordination of L 4 . Packing of 1D chains (c) top and (d) side views. Notice that the channels are occupied by the water and PF6 ions. (e) Amide-to-amide hydrogen-bonded dimer, shown in the boxes of panels (c) and (d).
cln_elements.clean_text: 7  Illustrations for the crystal structure of 8: (a) 1D chain containing rectangular cavities which are occupied by water and PF6 ions (b) coordination of L  4 . Packing of 1D chains (c) top and (d) side views. Notice that the channels are occupied by the water and PF6 ions. (e) Amide-to-amide hydrogen-bonded dimer, shown in the boxes of panels (c) and (d).

cln_elements.content: Illustrations for the crystal structures of 9 and 10: (a) 2D layer of (4,4)-topology with ClO4 – and H2O in the rhomboidal cavities. (b) 2-Fold parallel interpenetration of the layers. Column of guests present in the channel viewed along the c axis for (c) benzonitrile molecules in 9 and (d) nitrobenzene molecules in 10. Assembling of the guest molecules within the column via the (e) C–H···N hydrogen bond for benzonitrile and (f) C–H···O hydrogen bond for nitrobenzene. (g) Channels of benzonitrile molecules viewed along the a axis and (h) interaction between the layers via anions and water molecules.
cln_elements.clean_text: 8  Illustrations for the crystal structures of 9 and 10: (a) 2D layer of (4,4)-topology with ClO4 - and H2O in the rhomboidal cavities. (b) 2-Fold parallel interpenetration of the layers. Column of guests present in the channel viewed along the c axis for (c) benzonitrile molecules in 9 and (d) nitrobenzene molecules in 10. Assembling of the guest molecules within the column via the (e) C-H⋅⋅⋅N hydrogen bond for benzonitrile and (f) C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bond for nitrobenzene. (g) Channels of benzonitrile molecules viewed along the a axis and (h) interaction between the layers via anions and water molecules.
